titles.title: Agichide - Assiniboin, from The North American Indian

makers.displaydate: 1868–1952; born Whitewater, WI; died Los Angeles, CA; active Seattle, WA and Los Angeles, CA
makers.displaymaker: Edward Sheriff Curtis, 1868–1952; born Whitewater, WI; died Los Angeles, CA; active Seattle, WA and Los Angeles, CA

texts.textentryhtml: The North American Indian, by American photographer and ethnographer Edward Sheriff Curtis, was a twenty-volume series of photogravures, published from 1907 to 1930, that presented the societies and cultures of Native Americans living in the United States and Canada west of the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers. Curtis was inspired by the then-common assumption that Native American peoples and their traditional lifestyles were destined to "vanish" with the unstoppable progress of modernity. Today, Curtis’s project stands as a monument to the impact of the "vanishing race" theory on representations of Native Americans, and it has provoked important questions about the clouding of artistic intention and the power dynamics of such an enterprise. Curtis was so keen to create his vision of these peoples that he staged, posed, and possibly even costumed some of his sitters in ways that depicted not their daily lives but ones he imagined for them.
texts.remarks: Franz History of Photography Rotation July 2017

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Princeton University Art Museum 2015," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 75/76 (2016-17): 102-125.
